title: Cricket Statistics — Who is the Best Batsman?
summary: Using descriptive statistics and probability to compare cricketers' performances across different conditions — a quintessentially Indian application of data analysis.
content:
Case Study: Cricket Statistics

Cricket is India's most popular sport, and it generates enormous amounts of data. Comparing two batsmen — say, Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma — requires more than just looking at batting averages. We need measures of consistency (standard deviation), performance under pressure (conditional probability), and trend analysis (regression).

Key Mathematical Concepts

  • Batting Average: Total runs / number of dismissals — the mean of a dataset.
  • Standard Deviation: Measures consistency; a low σ means the batsman scores similarly each time.
  • Conditional Probability: P(scoring 50+ | away match) captures performance under difficult conditions.
  • Regression Analysis: Identifying trends in a player's form over time.

Real-World Impact

Modern cricket teams use sophisticated analytics to make selection decisions, set batting orders, and develop bowling strategies. The mathematics of statistics directly translates to competitive advantage on the field.
